Dot Product

  //   Topics: Linear Algebra

Let \(\pmb {\vec u = (u_1, u_2, . . . , u_n)}\) and \(\pmb {\vec v = (v_1, v_2, . . . , v_n)}\) be two vectors.

The dot product is a scalar defined by:

\[\pmb {\vec u \cdot \vec v = u_1 v_1 + u_2 v_2 + . . . + u_n v_n}\]

\(\pmb {\vec u}\) and \(\pmb {\vec v}\) are orthogonal if their dot product is \(\pmb {0}\).
